(ref: q.php?date=202011241721)11.24.205:21 pm  you've talked a lot about how you write through a song (linearly), but this has me wondering -- what are some procedures you use for re-drafting a song?

do you ever find it difficult to put your song ideas into the song?
occasionally
And if yes how do you manage to do so?

first, i must figure out whether the 'idea' is supposed to be the beginning of the song, or not the beginning. if it's the beginning, then just run through it in real time and then have more ideas while already in the song. if the idea is the middle, this is much more difficult because then you have to figure out what came before, which is like writing backwards. which for me is almost impossible. but i have developed some tricks for this, such as asking a trillion questions, trying 100 things, or, seeing what comes AFTER, and then continue from there and hope that somewhere along the line a beginning reveals itself in some kind of cyclical construct

In "La de da de da de da de day oh" you rhymed "mall" 3 times, was there any hidden meaning behind that?

yes, this is what it is: After selecting this song for recording, i felt deep dread and regret the next day. basically there is a lot of anxiety around selecting a song to record and do a music video for, because unfortunately, for some unknown reason, i always make my songrecordings and videos very complicated. so it is a large commitment when choosing a song. At the time of selection, the song was only written up to the end of the first chorus. So i was feeling a deep amount of regret, the day after selecting it. but changing it would increase all doubts all around, because it had been a very thorough selection process, and if i invalidated that it would cast even larger shadows of doubt on the entire ability to select a song. So i was sitting in the waiting chairs for a haircut, just being very unsure of how to carry forward with the song, ... i had already attempted to change my mind earlier in the morning, to a much slower and sadder song. and i found myself circling back again to 'la de da', and just at the exact moment i was getting into the haircut chair, i let my mind turn to what i think might happen next, in the writing. obviously we are going into the second verse. And it's moments like these, when we say 'what if', that suddenly a blitz of writing comes. The first 3 lines of the second verse came at me very quickly. the relentlessness of the word 'mall' had a nice momentum to it, and certainly helped to plunge me into confidence that the song was the right choice, and by the time i got into the chair, i was certain i would be doing that song. the 4th line, however, did not come at all, and i had to force it later in the actual writing session and i am to this day not proud of it. so if i could summerize the answer to your original question, the meaning of the triple mall is 'momentum'

what's a song writing process look like for you? do you have something set you do every time or is it just organic?

at any time, anywhere, ideas can fall on me. even in dreams. that is one part of the process. learning to catch these is crucial to this part of the process. about 70% of the strongest ideas come unexpectedly, not during a songwriting session. So they must be captured and cataloged properly. At that time usually no work is done beyond the capture of the idea. Alternatively, to generate ideas, a more deliberate idea generation session can occur. this is planned, when you try to come up with ideas. remembering a key principle which is that songs can come from literally anywhere, there may be various clever strategies about which places to look. the fun part is, because they can come from anywhere, there is no limit to the places you can look. But still, this is just idea generation, separate from the remainder of the songwriting work. it's still just an idea generation session. Then there is the 'work', which is when you tend to entries in the catalog. depending on the situation, you may be tasked to finish an entire item, or just part of it, before moving onto another. But in either case, you are essentially playing hospital with the song. diagnose it, figure out what it is, what it wants to be, what it's meant to be, etc, and make decisions accordingly. 95% of the time i work strictly forwards, only being concerned with what comes next, and continuing along in order, forwards. The only situation where i would be forced to work backwards is if the original idea does not belong at the beginning. then it's a puzzle to fill in what came before, which seems to defy all laws of physics for me. very unusual. but it can be done and there are various tricks which work with varying degrees of effectiveness. So the majority of the songwriting process (basically all of it except the initial idea seed) follows the same idea of figuring out what comes next. so there are a few important practices that always seem to hold true. agree on an exact tempo as soon as you can, and run a metronome to keep from drifting. this avoids a crisis where you've drifted the tempo and now you may be writing at a level of density which is never gonna fit at the same tempo as what you've already written elsewhere in the song. another important concept is the fact that you really only know what's best the FIRST time you hear it. so you have to do whatever you can to protect this authentic, real time run through, from the mindset of never having heard it before. of course, when you're working, you're inevitably gonna hear it many times. a standard trick i use to help 're-set' is to walk to the door and touch the door handle (with the metronome running) and return and run-through from the beginning. it's also important to remember, full run-throughs are much much more valuable than only running the last part. the full-run through is the only thing that's going to truly reveal where we are at, at a certain point in the song, and thus to properly determine what happens (or does not happen) next. Another thing to realize, if nothing seems to be working and you keep trying things and ditching them, it's important to recognize that the ideas get worse the more you reject them. so if you reject 3 ideas, the 4th will be worse. so if you get too deep into a hole of rejecting, it can be useful to recognize that the first one might be the best one you're gonna get, and make extra effort to try to make the first one work, because in that case it's usually your best shot. Finally, another interesting trick which i've been using a lot recently is, pretend it's in a video. pretend it's taking place in a movie, inside a story. This doesn't even mean you're gonna write a video, but sometimes just pretending it's taking place in a video, will immediately cause interesting songwriting to materialize effortlessly. it's bizarre, because many times when this technique is working, it's not even associated with any particular video content. it's just because you told yourself to pretend you are thinking of visual content, this somehow creates an automatic trigger for songwriting

How do different sounds make nicer sounds together?

niceness is a product of our consciousness. from what i can tell, the way this game usually works is by making patterns and breaking them. So in this way, it's impossible to determine if any 1 item is nice, or if any 2 items together are nice. i can promise you, for as many situations as you might find where 2 items seems nicer than one, there is also a similar sister-scenario out there where 1 thing seems nicer than 2. what is the new video making process like?

first, i think i can do everything. which overwhelms me, because i don't know which thing to do. i'll tell you exactly how it happened. i was on a brand new break-neck schedule, where i was supposed to finish a song/video every 2 weeks, which was so much tighter than i had ever previously done it (at least 4x quicker), that no one believed was possible. so this is supposedly the first song of this new scheme, which essentially seems more like a dare at this point, because it's so absurd. So i had spent an entire day songwriting and i pretty much only made it through 2 stanzas. so the next day i had to kick myself and realize that this schedule is so ridiculous that i need to finish the song in the next 4 hours or it's pretty much game over. the 'sign' bit is the first bit to be written under that assumption. so in a way you can probably assume that this is the feeling of realizing i am going to have to steamroll the entire remainder of the songwriting process for this song. And i should clarify, steamrolling sometimes leads to fantastic growth, and i am thrilled with where the song ends up going, especially toward the end. and i don't think it would have ever gone like that, had the prior steamrolling not occured. it's a lesson that continues to play out again and again in the creative process, in the context of a world with limited time and resources

i've spent basically every bit of time i can in the past few years working on my music, instruments, and mixing as well as getting completely obsessed with video as well. realizing that i will be like this for the foreseeable future (and it keeps getting more obsessive and intense) i feel like i am getting more and more disconnected from reality (whatever that means). while i "know" many people from working on songs and production for other artists, i feel more and more disconnected and unsure of what a friend is and what music even is. this obsession only happened in these past few years, before i had played instruments just because it felt like an obvious thing to do, but without any real intention of making something. people i "used to know" have been very worried about my mental health due to the drastic change over time and how little time i have for anything other than working constantly on art. i find all this extremely hard to explain proper ly to so meone, and i haven't found anyone that seems like they actually understand what i'm trying to do (i don't know if i do sometimes). the thing im worried about is how i can get myself to take breaks effectively and somehow divert my obsessive attention into something "fun" that is unrelated sometimes. nothing is fun unless im working on a project;everything other than that just feels like a crazy waste of time as well. anyway, do you have any suggestions about learning how to effectively take breaks? i've tried various meditation techniques with little success. the only thing that really seems to work decently is going on a reeaaally long walk, and then i sometimes notice that i haven't had a conscious thought in minutes, and it is both a scary and good feeling at the same time.

You say you are normal a lot, but i don't think you are. it's not normal to isolate yourself and work almost constantly in the pursuit of artistic greatness for years and years . it's not normal to record yourself almost constantly and archive all the recordings, then edit them together later to craft a narrative of your progress.it's not normal to have such a deep analytical understanding of music as you do. it's not normal to have a website dedicated to documenting almost everything you've ever created. Obviously there are people who do this/have done this, but it is a small minority stilland thus not normal. it seems like you know you're not normal and that's why you feel the need to keep insisting that you are. i'm not saying it's bad not to be normal, i think it's good, if you were normal then i wouldn't even know who you were or be sending you this message.Are you afraid of being abnormal?
no, i'm extremely proud of it. i've actually been so audaciously proud of it for so many years that my PR team has advised me to please downplay it

When do you plan to release ur next video.

my first plan was march 26, 2019. then i made some bold new discoveries and worked on it for a long long time, not having any clue of when it would be done. then i made some even bolder discoveries which totally sidelined that video, then after a long long time of further experiments and development, somewhere around august 2020 i threw a dozen panic attacks simultaneously and made another plan for oct 6, 2020. but this was innacurate of course, again because of the fact that the whole process and procedure is essentially brand new. so basically i've been working steadily on the video ever since then, at a somewhat defeated and disheartened pace. so if i were to make up a due date, it would hold no validity at this point due to so many past failures. however, i am still working on the same item since late august 2020, and it is an ordinary song/video of average size. things are going quite well, and some brand new doors have been opened and will continue to open over the next 5 to 10 years, in terms of the content that will be made. however, the other side of the coin is that i am face to face with the imminent threat of complete ineptitude, simply due to my ongoing tendency to overestimate what i am capable of. this has plagued me for my entire life, and probably will require a more definitive solution than i've had before, if i intend to continue producing creatively for the rest of my life. which i do of course, even if just to catch up with the things i've already written. and that's not even including the fact that my propensity for writing has only amplified even more with each passing year, as it always has

im teaching my nephews piano and i wanted to get your thoughts and ideas on how im approaching it. for the younger ones i am first making sure they know where do is. then the rest of the white notes. teaching them how to sing a major scale. then i invite them to make a song up by plaiyng with the black keys, so they can have pentatonic fun. For the older one, he came to class knowing jingle bells. he likes learning songs. i am thinking of teaching him some chords to play along with jingle bells. but i also am teaching him a bit about the circle of fifths, how it relates to sharps and flats in different keys, and then showing him how jingle bells can be played starting in any note. I am very slowly trying to teach them how to read notes off a pentagram but I feel like that can dampen the excitement for the instrument if it becoems too "academized". I took a look at a teaching book and it doesnt look too fun tbh. maybe the best time to teach them to r ead musi c is when they want to learn a specific song? I can notate it for them and have them read off it? They range ages 4 to 10 probably. Some are more motivated than others but i feel they can all get excited about different aspects of piano/music/learning

how does daylight saving time actually work?

during the spring and summer months, the clock tells you a later time than it actually is. so it makes the evening seem a little lighter and the morning a little darker. this is besides the fact that the evening and morning are both already lighter than they were in the winter, but because of daylight saving, the evening is WAY more lighter, and the morning is ..... only a little bit lighter. it shifts the daylight later by 1 hour. in the springtime, when it changes, you will always hear people saying 'wow i can't believe it's still light at this time of evening', and in the fall when it switches back, you will hear people saying, 'wow i can't believe it's already dark at this time of evening.' However, what you may not hear, but is still said, is similar but reversed comments about the morning. But with a different twist, because it goes in the opposite direction of the way it's been heading. so, for example, in the springtime in the morning, after it changes, people in the early morning will be saying 'well, the mornings have been gradually getting lighter these past few weeks, but they just suddenly got darker again, although i know they are still going to gradually get ligher from here.' and in the fall, in the morning, just after it changes back, people in the early morning will say 'well, the mornings have been getting gradually darker over the past few weeks, but suddenly they just got brighter again, although i know they still will continue to get darker from here.'

do you have any thoughts to add about objectivity versus subjectivity in music? or anything creative for that matter?

objectivity and subjectivity are tools to determine which person is right and which person is wrong. the person who knows the words 'objectivity' and 'subjectivity' is always right, and here's how they do it: first they say 'subjectively', which means people are allowed to disagree. Then, they provide an alternate situation, 'objectively', which means there is only one right answer and you are not allowed to disagree with that. It's sort of like a good cop / bad cop scenario, where the 'subjectivity' scenario gives you a false sense of comfort, thinking it's ok for people to have different opinions, then the hammer comes down when 'objectively' there is only one true opinion, which spells checkmate for the other person of course

i am trying to write a play but it is becoming very difficult because I am starting to demand everything in the entire universe of myself. to execute any one of my ideas to its fullest potential will take about two years. this means that if i intend to give my play the time and dedication that it deserves, i will have to spend two years working on one play. the trouble with this is that i have so many ideas that i am so passionate about that it is impossible to commit myself to one over the others. people ask 'what kind of play do you want to write?' as if there is only one answer, as if a person's soul contains only one world. but that isn't really how it works in my experience. there are billions of plays i want to write and they are all equally important to me, but even if i live another thousand years i won't have enough time to do justice to all of them. basically, i am paralyzed by my own unreasonable expectations of myself. have you ever exper ienced t his?
